document.masterDocTitle: Taxonomic revision of the southern African genus Pachyphymus Uvarov, 1922 (Orthoptera: Acridoidea: Euryphyminae)

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 2.
Pachyphymus cristulifer Dirsh, 1956
: ♂ head, dorsal (A) and lateral view (B); ♂ head from Touwsrivier, showing intraspecific variation, dorsal (C) and lateral view (D); ♀ head from Leipoldtville, dorsal (E) and lateral view (F); ♀ subgenital plate (G), from Touwsrivier (H), and from Leipoldtville (I) showing intraspecific variation; ♂ supraanal plate (J), from Touwsrivier (K), and from Leipoldtville (L) showing intraspecific variation; epiphallus (M); phallic complex, ectophallic membrane removed, dorsal (N) and lateral view (O). Black scale bar refers to two phallic complex illustrations (N–O); dotted scale bar refers to epiphallus and supraanal plate (J–M); white scale bar refers to head images (A–F).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Dirsh 1956
: 132–136 >>
Pachyphymus cristulifer Dirsh 1965 : 258
>>
Pachyphymus cristulifer

Diagnostic redescription (male, except where specified). Wings. Tegmen surpassing end of abdomen and hind knee but not excessively so. Hind wing infumation dark brown or black, covering 50–70 % of wing, excluding wing interior but including apex; hind wing interior bright pink (
Figs. 6
H–I). This species is most similar to
P. namaquensis
n. sp.
but can be distinguished on the basis of the lower degree of hind wing infumation in the majority of specimens (compare
Fig.
6
I vs. 6 A), and the pointier male cercus (Fig. 5 H vs. 5 N).

Abdomen. Supraanal plate transverse, with a longitudinal concavity in the middle, lateral margins upcurved; posterior margin of supraanal plate with two lateral and one large median projection; supraanal plate with pair of large, strongly sclerotized tubercles in center of basal half (
Figs. 2
J–L). Apex of cercus elongate, terminating in point ranging from very sharp to blunted, descends and curves downwards into transverse curved ridge (Figs. 5 E– L).

Phallic complex. Epiphallus with short ancorae and broad, lobiform apically blunt lophi (
Fig. 2
M).

Female. Subgenital plate trilobate, with deep grooves separating lobes, large, pointed median lobe (
Figs. 2
G– I).

Remarks. Specimens from Touwsrivier were distinct morphologically from the rest of the species. They were smaller (
Fig. 9
E–F) had slightly different male cerci (Figs. 5 G–H), variable female subgenital plate (
Fig. 2
H), male supraanal plate (
Fig. 2
K), and a slightly greater degree of infumation on the hind wing with a distinct border between the infumated and colorful areas of the wing (
Fig. 6
H).

There was a distinct series of specimens from the region to the west of the Cederberg mountain range, from Leipoldtville, Eland’s Bay and Paleisheuwel to Wuppertal in the East (see GPS coordinates above). This group of specimens was the only one to exhibit variation in wing pattern and color. Wings varied from lightly to heavily infumated, with interior regions ranging from translucent to orange-pink to bright pink (
Figs. 6
E–G). The geographic location of this group of organisms is relatively isolated by the Cederberg mountain range, and
P. namaquensis
is geographically more accessible than the majority of
P. cristulifer
. Wing color and infumation polymorphism is common in several species of Oedipodinae, particularly in association with soil coloration, presumably as a means of camouflage. While the same has not yet been shown for the Euryphyminae , it is possibly similar, and, therefore, wing pattern and coloration should only be used as a diagnostic character in association with other characters, particularly sexually selected ones. While there is slight variation in the other features of this population of
P. cristulifer
(
Figs. 2
E–F,
2 I
, 2 L,
5 I
–J) the variation falls within the threshold of normal intraspecific variation.
